the war on inflation has acquired a positional character - the rise in prices fizzles out, while the corresponding increase in supply has not yet affected the markets. The question is - what will happen when it reaches the consumer, in parallel with the reduction of the balance sheets of central banks, the depletion of benefits accumulated during the covid period and the growth of rates? Do we not see deflation at a distance of 2-3 years in a foggy distance than 10 years ago, and how to combine this vision with a gradual verticalization of the risk-free asset yield curve? choose a company with a stable cash flow.

American Airlines Group (NASDAQ:AAL) had its target price increased by equities researchers at Morgan Stanley from $21.00 to $23.00 in a research report issued to clients and investors on Tuesday, Benzinga reports. The brokerage currently has an "underweight" rating on the airline's stock. Morgan Stanley's price target would suggest a potential upside of 19.11% from the stock's current price. $UAL $LUV $DAL

Here are my reflections on the day, as it relates to airline stocks...UAL closed at a solid +1.39%, which may seem like peanuts if you think it was up 4% an hour before close. However, a stock that has been hammered like the airline industry has in the last 2 months, is unlikely going to close any higher than 2% on a single day (unless there is a huge catalyst). Day traders who have bought the dip will take their profits before the bell rings. Which is exactly what happened today.Ultimately the industry will be back as soon as vaccinations start being at a good level and infections drop below an acceptable one as well. If you are looking to make a quick profit with the likes of $UAL, $AAL or $DAL, you are in the wrong place. But if you are looking for growth in the next 3 or so months and have bought in at July - August prices, you will be doing well.Anyway, good luck to you all.
